Tuesday 14th October

6pm – 9.30pm

[/vc_column_text][vc_video link=”https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gwdToH75WOM” css=””][vc_column_text css=”.vc_custom_1754920606927{margin-top: 30px !important;margin-bottom: 30px !important;}” text_direction=”default”]

Black Women Business Talks offers Black women a space to accelerate their business growth and career success. This event brings together accomplished business leaders and thriving entrepreneurs to share transformative strategies for authentic leadership, personal growth, and sustainable success.

Through inspiring talks, intimate panel discussions, and meaningful networking opportunities, attendees will gain practical insight on how to navigate industry challenges, build unshakeable confidence, and create impact on their own terms.

Whether you’re an aspiring entrepreneur, established business owner, or climbing the corporate ladder, this event provides the tools, connections, and inspiration needed to unlock your full potential.

Key themes:
1. Architect your career on your own terms and design work that brings meaning, purpose and flexibility to your life
2. Master the art of strategic networking to build game-changing relationships to accelerate your growth
3. Build an authentic personal brand that amplifies your unique voice and unlocks powerful new opportunities
4. Develop a CEO mindset to confidently lead teams and create the inclusive culture you want to work in
5. Achieve sustainable success by perfecting the art of work-life balance, prioritising self-development, and using change as a catalyst for transformation

Karen Blackett CBE

Business Leader, Former UK President, WPP & Former CEO, GroupM
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Karen is a proven business leader with a track record in creating vibrant cultures, energising teams, and consistently delivering business growth and success. She is the former UK President for WPP, the world’s largest marketing services group, and responsible for driving growth in WPP’s second largest market of 13,000 people. As former GroupM UK CEO, Karen was selected to turnaround the business over 2.5 years at a critical time, during the COVID global pandemic and the subsequent impact of the killing of George Floyd.

In June 2014, Karen received an OBE in the Queen’s Birthday honours and topped the Power List, being the first businesswoman to come in at number 1. Karen founded The Black Equity Organisation in 2021, alongside David Lammy MP, David Olusoga OBE, Kwame Kwei-Armah OBE, Ric Lewis and Dame Vivian Hunt. BEO is an independent, national Black civil rights organisation created to dismantle systemic racism in Britain, drive generational change and deliver better lived experiences for Black people across the country.[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ divider_color=”default” custom_height=”20″][vc_row_inner equal_height=”yes” content_placement=”middle” Esther Appiagyei

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Esther Appiagyei, also known as The Queen Hadassah from her YouTube days, is a renowned makeup artist with over 15 years of experience in the beauty industry. Specializing in celebrity, bridal, commercial and television makeup. Esther’s work has been featured in prestigious magazines such as Vogue. She has also worked with high-profile clients from  Ayra Starr to Busayo Saka, and worked on campaigns for brands such as Burberry, Snickers, and New Balance.

Known for her ability to enhance natural beauty and create stunning looks, Esther is passionate about empowering her clients, leaving them feeling beautiful from the inside out. Her warm and personable approach has earned her a loyal clientele and lasting relationships. Esther is also dedicated to teaching women makeup skills for themselves, believing in the confidence that makeup can bring.

In addition to her professional work, Esther is a dedicated mentor and educator, conducting classes to inspire the next generation of makeup artists. Her creativity, and commitment to excellence make her a long standing figure in the makeup industry.[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ divider_color=”default” Jordan Mitchell

Co-Founder, Good Culture & Good Sport[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Jordan Mitchell is the co-founder of Good Culture and Good Sport, two agencies known for shaping how brands and talent show up meaningfully in culture. With over a decade of experience across corporate, entertainment, and creative industries, Jordan brings a unique blend of commercial acumen and cultural insight to her work.

Having started her career within leading corporate environments, Jordan transitioned into brand and talent strategy with a focus on long-term impact. She has since led cultural positioning and partnership strategy for brands such as Barbour, Creed, Pattern, Flannels, Airbnb, SKIMS, Marc Jacobs, and Good American. Her strategic work also extends to talent working with the likes of Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, Dina Asher-Smith, Alessia Russo, Naomi Schiff, Rochelle Humes, Clara Amfo, and Sabrina Elba through narrative development, brand alignment, and global visibility.

Jordan regularly contributes to wider industry conversations through platforms like The Telegraph and Grazia, where she writes on topics spanning diversity, motherhood, and career evolution offering a personal perspective on the shifting dynamics of modern leadership.[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ divider_color=”default” custom_height=”20″][vc_row_inner Jamelia Donaldson

Founder and CEO, TreasureTress[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Jamelia Donaldson is Founder and CEO of TreasureTress, Europe’s largest subscription service dedicated to curly hair product discovery. TreasureTress not only addresses the lack of quality products for curly hair in the UK but also nurtures a vibrant and interconnected community that transcends geographical boundaries.

Jamelia’s influence extends far beyond TreasureTress. Recognizing the beauty industry’s disregard for Black and Multi-Ethnic consumers, she has spearheaded a consultancy arm within her company, empowering brands worldwide to establish authentic connections and find their rightful place within this underserved market. Jamelia’s expertise and transformative work has been featured in renowned publications such as Forbes, Buzzfeed, and The Times. Jamelia has also unveiled TreasureTress’ first official TREND REPORT: “The Untapped Opportunity: in the UK Afro Hair Market.”[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ divider_color=”default” custom_height=”20″][vc_row_inner Annisha Taylor

Head of Equality, Diversity & Inclusion (EDI), Ofcom[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Annisha is a pioneering culture and change strategist with over 15 years’ experience driving equality, diversity and inclusion (EDI) across the public, private, and voluntary sectors. Currently Head of EDI at Ofcom, she has held influential roles at the BBC and John Lewis Partnership, shaping inclusive behaviours and systems within media, regulatory and retail landscapes.

Her work is rooted in collaboration, accountability and measurable impact, qualities that make her a discerning voice when assessing what works. Annisha is known for translating complex cultural challenges into actionable strategies that improve workplace wellbeing, belonging and performance, while holding initiatives to the highest standards of integrity and delivery.

Outside her professional roles, Annisha is a Fellow of the Institute for Equity University Centre and serves as a Trustee at The BRIT School. She is also a dedicated community leader and primary school governor, advocating for inclusive education, culture & business.[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ Mose Adigun

Managing Director – Head of EMEA Technology M&A, J.P. Morgan[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Mose Adigun is a Managing Director in the Investment Banking group, leading J.P. Morgan’s EMEA Technology M&A practice.  Mose joined the firm in 2008 and spent the first 10 years of her career in the UK Corporate Finance and M&A team, working on a broad range of public and private M&A as well as UK capital markets transactions. She then moved into a client coverage role, taking responsibility for key client relationships across Tech, Media and Telecoms in the UK. Mose moved back into the M&A group in 2025, and now focuses on originating and executing M&A transactions across Tech in EMEA.[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ Shauna Roper

Chief of Staff, Global Procurement, HSBC[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Shauna Roper is not just a business leader, she is a movement. As a multi-award winning executive, transformation architect, and mother of two, Shauna has built her life around one unshakeable principle: you are the CEO of you. 

With two decades in global finance and a legacy of empowering women and underrepresented talent, Shauna blends strategic insight with lived experience. From boardrooms to grassroots programmes, she has consistently driven transformational impact, reshaping how leadership looks and feels. 

As the Chief of Staff for Global Procurement in a multi billion dollar organisations, and the former Global Head of Diversity & Inclusion for 25,000 FTE, Shauna has advised Group Executives, influenced Holdings Boards, and founded a women’s leadership empowerment programme that led to measurable promotions and performance shifts across the enterprise.[/vc_column_text][divider Tiwalola Adebayo

TEDx Speaker & Founder, Confident and Killing It[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Tiwalola Adebayo is an award-winning confidence coach, TEDx speaker, author, and founder of Confident and Killing It, a global movement dedicated to waking people up to their worth so they can become confident, unstoppable, and create the life they truly desire.

Through engaging workshops, transformative coaching programs, and powerful media content, Tiwalola equips ambitious individuals with the mindset and tools they need to overcome fear, silence self-doubt, and take bold action toward their biggest goals.

Her first book, Confident and Killing It, was published by HarperCollins in July 2022 to much acclaim, inspiring thousands to step into their power.

Since launching in 2018, she has empowered over 10,000 people worldwide and delivered dynamic experiences for some of the world’s leading brands and organizations, including Google, Meta, The Times, Deloitte, Morgan Stanley, ViacomCBS, Spotify, Squarespace, UN Women UK, and The Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy.[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ Chisola Chitambala

Apprentice Finalist & Co-Founder, CB Virtual Assistant[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]Chisola Chitambala is an entrepreneur and co-founder of CB Virtual Assistant, a business that predominantly helps entrepreneurs and SMEs streamline their operations through virtual support. She most recently rose to national recognition after reaching the final five on the 2025 edition of The Apprentice UK (Season 19), finishing 4th.

With a background as a paediatric nurse and an MBA to support her transition into entrepreneurship, Chisola’s journey is rooted in adaptability, purpose, and resilience.

She has recently taken on the role of Deputy Head of Commercial Education and Events at Guy’s and St Thomas’ NHS Foundation Trust. She is the first-ever Ambassador for The Migraine Trust, using her platform to raise awareness and champion wellbeing. She is also a Patron of the National Diversity Awards.[/vc_column_text][divider line_type=”Full Width Line” line_thickness=”1″ divider_color=”default” custom_height=”20″][vc_row_inner Justice Williams

Co-Founder & Editor in Chief, Black Business Magazine[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]

Justice Williams MBE is a personal branding expert, business strategist, and award-winning entrepreneur dedicated to helping women turn their expertise into profit. As the founder of Black Business Magazine and Elevate, her premium membership for female entrepreneurs, she has built a platform that empowers women to grow profitable and purpose-driven brands. She is the Vice Chair of the Greater Birmingham Chamber of Commerce, Black Business Collective.

Justice is also the founder of TEDxLadywood Women and the host of the Dream Plan Launch podcast, where she shares insights on personal branding, business, and mindset. As the co-founder of two kids, Justice balances entrepreneurship with motherhood, championing financial empowerment and opportunities for women.

Amarachi Anogwi

Service Delivery Lead, Capgemini [/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]

Amarachi Anogwi is a celebrated Service Delivery Lead at Capgemini whose journey into tech is as inspiring as it is unconventional.A former teacher and mother of four, Amarachi discovered programming while facing extraordinary adversity. With no formal STEM background and self-confessed struggles in mathematics, she retrained and joined Capgemini as a Software Engineer in 2022. Her rapid rise to leadership reflects her resilience, excellence, and commitment to breaking barriers.

Amarachi is an award-winning advocate for diversity and inclusion, a STEM UK Ambassador, and a Core Leadership Member of the Black Women at Capgemini network. She speaks passionately about digital transformation, equity in tech, and empowering women to lead boldly and rewrite their narratives.

Joelle Owusu-Sekyere

Black British Business Awards Finalist & Editorial Director, Penguin Random House[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_column_text css=”” text_direction=”default”]

Joelle Owusu-Sekyere is Editorial Director at #Merky Books, Penguin Random House, where she acquires fiction and non-fiction. She was recently recognised as a finalist for the Black British Business Awards Arts & Media Rising Star Category, showcasing the impact of her work.

Formerly Editorial Director at Dialogue Books and Commissioning Editor at Hodder & Stoughton, her acquisitions include Nero Prize-shortlisted The Tidal Year and Sunday Times bestsellers Glittering a Turd and Finding Me by Viola Davis.

After a BSc in Petroleum Geology, she pivoted to publishing. Joelle regularly speaks at festivals including Cheltenham and Edinburgh, and has contributed to BBC Radio 5 Live since 2019. She also mentors aspiring publishers and champions underrepresented voices across the literary landscape.

use_theme_fonts=”yes”][vc_column_text css=”.vc_custom_1694169062752{margin-top: 30px !important;margin-bottom: 30px !important;}”]The Fearless Foundation and UK Black Business Week are collaborating to present a Fearless Pitch Competition to win $10,000 as part of the Black Women Business Talks programming this year. 

This initiative aims to address the global issue of inadequate capital access for Women of Color. Despite comprising 20.3% of the US population, they received less than 0.4% of funding in 2022. The UK faces similar challenges, with Black female startup founders receiving only 0.34% of venture capital. 

*Note: you must have a ticket for Black Women Business Talks – Tuesday 3rd October, to be considered.

Apply here >>
